block.p: Barak Recalls Negotiators After Attack in West Bank Prime Minister Ehud Barak recalled his peace negotiators from Sweden after a firebomb critically wounded a 2-year-old Israeli girl in a car passing through the Palestinian-ruled city of Jericho. Palestinian officials denounced Mr. Barak for pushing away from the peace table, saying it would lead to further deterioration and increased tensions.

Yugoslavia Wary of Students Otpor, a Serbian student movement demanding sweeping political change, is surging in popularity and is now a significant target for attack by the government of the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic.

Agreement on Nuclear Arms At the end of a monthlong conference of more than 185 nations at the United Nations, the five original atomic powers powers agreed for the first time to the elimination of nuclear arms. The move gives at least a psychological boost to flagging efforts to contain and abolish nuclear weapons.

Swiss Move Closer to Union Swiss voters, breaking with their tradition of isolationism, approved a set of agreements that lifts barriers to trade and commerce with the rest of Europe. The government hopes the accords are a step toward joining the European Union.

Too Few Voters for Italy Reform A referendum aimed at reducing the instability in Italy's electoral system was invalidated because only about 32 percent of voters cast ballots, far less than the 50.1 percent needed.

Elections in Haiti Haitians overcame fears of violence and crowded into polling places to elect thousands of legislators and local officials with the hope that their country would finally escape the political paralysis that has crippled it the past three years.

Beijing's One-China Stipulation Beijing restated that its ''one China'' principle is an absolute precondition of strengthening ties with Taiwan. The official New China News Agency issued the commentary in response to the inaugural speech by President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan.

Clinton Draws 12,000 To Fund-Raising Event President Clinton is to headline the most lucrative political fund-raising event in political history on Wednesday, collecting at least $25 million from 12,000 donors at the M.C.I. Center in Washington. The event will cement the president's legacy as the most prodigious political fund-raiser ever.

Gore Ahead in Fund-Raising Gov. George W. Bush of Texas raised three times more money than Vice President Al Gore last month, but Mr. Gore made up the difference with taxpayer funds and continued to have more money in the bank than his Republican opponent.
19 Killed in Plane Crash A charter plane carrying 19 people from Atlantic City, N.J., to Wilkes-Barre, Pa., apparently developed engine trouble and crashed, killing everyone aboard.

Crowded Footbridge Collapses A pedestrian bridge at Lowe's Motor Speedway in Concord, N.C., site of the Winston stock car race, snapped on Saturday night, injuring 107 people. Fifty-three remained hospitalized.

Blast in Los Angeles An explosion possibly caused by a large fireworks device tore through an apartment building in Los Angeles yesterday morning, injuring at least one resident. A man believed to be responsible for the explosion suffered injuries to his hands and face, but was not hospitalized. Several hundred people were evacuated from the building and the rest of the block.

Thalidomide Shows Promise The early promise of thalidomide as an anti-cancer drug apparently is holding up, according to findings disclosed at the meeting of the American Society of Clinical Oncology in New Orleans.

Asthma Data Lacking Data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows that most states have no system to track the number of people with asthma or monitor what happens to them, and only a few states have any recent reports on the illness in their jurisdictions.

Recruiting Success Favored Bishop Egan Bishop Egan has vigorously recruited men for the priesthood, ordaining a higher proportion of priests than any other diocese in the Northeast. His success weighed heavily in his nomination to head the New York Archdiocese, said one church official involved in the process, a sign that the Vatican considers the shortage a serious problem.

Giuliani Offers Sympathy Mayor Giuliani, in an intensely personal interview broadcast on NBC's ''Meet the Press,'' said that he has ''sympathy, concern and compassion'' for the family of Patrick M. Dorismond, a Haitian-American man killed by the police in March.

Offender Lists Go Online States around the country are going a step beyond sex offender registries, posting that information, along with photographs and sordid details of crimes, on Web pages. Since 1996, 21 states, mostly in the South and the Midwest, have put the registries on the Internet.

Lazio Campaigns for Senate Representative Rick A. Lazio scrambled to present himself to voters in four cities in upstate New York as a viable statewide alternative to his opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton.
Danish Movie Wins at Cannes The Danish director Lars von Trier's musical melodrama ''Dancer in the Dark'' won the Golden Palm for best movie at the Cannes International Film Festival awards ceremony.
Knicks Head to Finals The Knicks upset the Heat, 83-82, and advanced to the finals against Indiana.
Barbara Cartland A romance writer whose outpouring of more than 700 novels during seven decades made her the undisputed queen of a genre for hundreds of millions of readers, she was 98.

Vodafone AirTouch Mulls Plan Vodafone AirTouch is considering selling the fixed-line assets it acquired when it bought Mannesmann and speeding up the sale of Orange, a British Britain's third-largest cellular operator, to raise more than $60 billion, said executives close to the company.
Copyright Law Update Sought A Democratic research center is recommending that a law to protect intellectual property on the Internet be updated.

Alteon Alliance Planned Alteon intends to announce this week that it has enlisted two powerful allies -- Lucent Technologies and Akamai Technologies -- in a move to stay competitive after Cisco Systems agreed to acquire Arrowpoint.

Busy Times for Optical Sector The world of ''next generation optical networking'' is heating up. Mayan Networks, a start-up, plans today to announce the availability of its first product. And ONI Systems intends to make an initial public offering of its stock tomorrow.
Stocks Plunge in Tokyo Stocks were sharply lower in Tokyo today. In morning trading, the Nikkei index was down 540.02 points, or 3.2 percent.
